cells.reasonOutOfScope: Avaloq Core Banking System security assessment is not feasible as out of CLX System boundaries.
Avaloq Core Banking System security assessment is not feasible as out of CLX System boundaries.
Avaloq Core Banking System security assessment is not feasible as out of CLX System boundaries.

threats.title: AMI credentials in plaintext
threats.description: AMI CLXE$EBANKINGADMIN credentials are stored in etcd which, by default, is not encrypted and neither are its secrets.
threats.mitigation: Confidentiality risk must be mitigated by guaranteeing encryption at rest. This can be done by enabling Kubernetes encryption at rest feature. The top-level/master key should ideally be stored outside of the cluster.

threats.title: Missing etcd least privilege
threats.description: Allowing components within the cluster to access the master etcd instance with read or write access to the full keyspace is equivalent to granting cluster-admin access.
threats.mitigation: Use etcd ACLs to restrict read/write access to a subset of they keyspace is strongly recommended

threats.title: Sensitive data exposure
threats.description: There is no confirmed mechanism for removing or obfuscating sensitive information based on relevant data classification assigned to data objects.
threats.mitigation:
Sensitive data should not be stored or logged unnecessarily. 
Strict permissions concerning which users can access logs must be verified prior to project rollout.

threats.title: Message Tampering
threats.description: RabbitMQ does not perform integrity checks. This exposes the entire Message Broker instance to the risk of message being tampered with, should access control flaws or RabbitMQ misconfiguration enable it.
threats.mitigation: An integrity protection can be applied to the publishing and consuming applications, like computing a checksum and adding it as a message header. Similarly to the above, the control would possibly be done between the 2 ends of the communication, through an additional header.

threats.title: Lack of message encryption
threats.description: Current design does not involve encryption of the messages within RabbitMQ. This implies a confidentiality breach for private, sensitive or highly sensitive information being disclosed to unauthorised users for furtherly leveraging business/user data.
threats.mitigation: Message payloads should be passed via RabbitMQ exchanges and queues in an encrypted form. The Module Gateway component should offer encryption/decryption for every producer and consumer applications and in line with the CISO cryptographic specification.

threats.title: AMI/RabbitMQ credentials in plaintext
threats.description: AMI CLXE$EBANKINGADMIN and RabbitMQ credentials are stored in etcd which, by default, is not encrypted and neither are its secrets.
threats.mitigation:
Confidentiality risk must be mitigated by guaranteeing encryption at rest. This can be done by enabling Kubernetes encryption at rest feature. The top-level/master key should ideally be stored outside of the cluster.

Use OAuth2 Client Credentials grant for RabbitMQ to verify the authentication of the Hub Module

threats.title: Missing etcd least privilege
threats.description: Allowing components within the cluster to access the master etcd instance with read or write access to the full keyspace is equivalent to granting cluster-admin access.
threats.mitigation: Use etcd ACLs to restrict read/write access to a subset of they keyspace is strongly recommended
